questions.text: Universal publicly funded healthcare (a National Health Insurance-style system) should be established to provide free basic care to everyone.
Higher education should be free for all students (no fees), not just means-tested financial aid.
The state should implement an unconditional basic income grant for all citizens, even if it requires higher taxes or borrowing.
The government should raise taxes on the wealthy to fund expanded social programmes (health, education and social grants).
Government should invest heavily in public housing for low-income families.
Public housing investment should take priority even if it requires cutting other public services.
Rural development and agricultural support (including subsidies and infrastructure for small farmers) should receive significantly more government funding.
Workers should have stronger rights to strike and negotiate directly with employers without government interference.
BEE and affirmative action should remain central government priorities to redress historic racial and economic inequality.
Expropriation of private land without market-rate compensation should be permitted under law to accelerate land reform.
The Constitution should be amended where necessary to speed up transformation and enable more progressive redistribution.
South Africa should prioritise trade agreements that protect local industries, even if it means higher consumer prices.
The country should prioritise investment in renewable energy (solar, wind) over expanding coal power.
Strong action against corruption (even if it disrupts current leaders) is more important than preserving political stability.
To reduce crime, the government should focus more on harsher punishment rather than addressing social causes like poverty.
Illegal immigrants should be deported and strict border control enforced to protect local jobs and resources.
The government should create large public works and job guarantee programmes to reduce unemployment.
Private property and small-business rights should be strongly protected against expropriation and heavy regulation.
The government should strengthen legal protections for LGBTQ+ people and actively advance equal civil rights.
The independence of the judiciary and prosecuting authorities must be strictly protected, even if that limits executive flexibility.
South Africa should prioritise broad multilateral diplomatic and trade engagement (with the EU, US and African neighbours) over aligning primarily with alternative geopolitical blocs.
The government should expand surveillance and data-access powers for law enforcement to fight crime and terrorism, even if it reduces some privacy.
